Headline: Nathaniel Roberts
Desc: At various points in his Highlands career, Nathaniel was Mr. Highlands Football, selected as Offensive Dominator, and given the Triple Threat Award. He lettered in three different sports, and maintained a cumulative 3.7 GPA on the academic side. Throughout his years at Highlands, he took part in and led both academic and athletic programs in Special Education. Nathaniel is intent on a career in Special Education as a teacher and coach, and is currently enrolled on that track at the University of Kentucky.

Headline: Will James Salmon
Desc: Will personifies the student-athlete profile the Scholarship seeks to support. Twice a football Captain, and recipient of the Red Dog Spirit Award  his junior year, Will's teachers, coaches and colleagues all speak of his determination, dedication and plain grit in whatever he takes on. He has serious teaching and coaching ambitions, with a particular focus on Special Education, and is at Northern Kentucky University.

Headline: McKenzie J. Leigh
Desc:
McKenzie was a four-year Super Honor Roll student-athlete at Highlands. She received the Presidential Award for 
Academic Excellence at Highlands and has the distinction of being a 2015 Kentucky Governor’s Scholar. Among 
other things at HHS she was a member of National Honor Society, National English Honor Society, National
Spanish Honor Society, and Future Business Leaders of America.  McKenzie was a three-year starter on the 
Varsity Girls Basketball team, receiving 5 Varsity letters and being a team captain her senior year.  She mas 
named the MVP of the LaRosas Holiday Classic Tournament in 2015 and to the 9th Region All-Tournament 
team in 2014, 2015, and 2016. In 2015, she received the Highlands High School David Cecil Citizenship 
Award by a unanimous vote from all the Varsity athletic coaches at Highlands. Combining both athletics 
and academics, she also received the Northern Kentucky High School Girls Basketball Coaches’ Association 
Division II Academic Award. 

McKenzie is attending the University of Kentucky, in addition to receiving the E.E. "Judge" Waddell Scholarship,
she has received the Presidential Scholarship which covers Full Tuition for four years. Her first semester produced
a 3.73 GPA.  

Congratulations!

Headline: Claudia Hils
Desc: Claudia was an outstanding student-athlete at Highlands, with a concentration in soccer. She was captain of a nationally-ranked soccer team , lettered three times, and coached an elementary soccer team, all while achieving a straight A academic record and serving in numerous leadership positions in her class and other organizations, including the National Honor Society. She is compiling a similarly impressive record at NKU, holding a number of leadership positions and a 4.0 GPA, and is still very committed to teaching and coaching.

Headline: Mallory Seidel
Desc:
Mallory was captain of the Highlands varsity volleyball team as a senior, after several standout years in that sport, including
being named MVP of her freshman team. Mallory was also a member of the tennis and track teams during her Highland years.  
Excellent academic achievement and numerous volunteer commitments rouded out a career that led the Scholarship Committee 
to name her our 2014 recipient.  Mallory is currently in her third year at the University of Louisville, working toward an 
Education degree, continuing her great volunteer work with everything from Special Olympics to Habitat for Humanity, 
and being elected VP of the U of L College of Education for 2016-2017.

Headline: Mallory Seidel
Desc:
Mallory was captain of the Highlands varsity volleyball team as a senior, after several standout years in that sport, including
being named MVP of her freshman team. Mallory was also a member of the tennis and track teams during her Highland years.  
Excellent academic achievement and numerous volunteer commitments rouded out a career that led the Scholarship Committee 
to name her our 2014 recipient.  Mallory is currently in her third year at the University of Louisville, working toward an 
Education degree, continuing her great volunteer work with everything from Special Olympics to Habitat for Humanity, 
and being elected VP of the U of L College of Education for 2016-2017.

Headline: Richie Whitford
Desc:
Richie played four years of football at Highlands, and was a team Captain in his senior year. Coach Mueller described him as "an inspiration...with regards to how hard he worked and how well he developed and played." His Highlands career also included the Honor Roll, the Super Honor Roll, the Spanish Club and FBLA. Throughout the years he spent countless volunteer hours for the benefit of churches and community on everything from Boosters Club fundraisers to the Soup Kitchen.

Educationally, Richie is headed for Elementary Education at the University of Kentucky. Our best wishes to him.

Headline: Brian Beck
Desc:
Brian was Mr. Highlands Football three times, and received the Red Dog Spirit Award, but obviously didn't neglect academics, 
as he made the Super Honor Roll and received the Silver Key Writing Award. Brian graduated from Northern Kentucky 
University, and engaged in student teaching as a part of the COST (Consortium for Overseas Student Teaching) program
at a high school in the Netherlands. 

We are proud to have one of our scholars involved in the vitally-important field of global education.  Brian has, at least for now,
chosen a sales career in the private sector.

Headline: Brady Dowling
Desc:
Played center for the Bluebirds football team and was elected captain his senior year. A real leader, Brady was a Freshman and Freshman 
Football Mentor in 2007-08, and received the Leader of Champions award in 2008. Brady received his B.A. and Masters Degrees 
from the University of Kentucky, in English and Educational Administration. He tutored students at Henry Clay High School, 
worked in the front office of the Lexington Legends (AA) baseball club, and did his student teaching in the Fayette County 
Public School System, all in and around Lexington.

In 2013, he became the first Waddell Scholar to accept a full-time teaching position in the Ft. Thomas system, teaching English and 
AP English courses at Highlands.  He has been head Freshman football coach for the past seven years.  
We are proud to have Brady become the first of our scholars to come home to Highlands.

In recalling his own formative years, Brady notes the "outstanding education the Highlands teachers and staff gave me in 
preparing me for writing and planning for exams", as well as the lesson "that friends and outside influences are just as 
important as having a good education. The social experience I had at Highlands...made it a seamless transition from 
high school to college. Being a part of the football team was also huge for me; football made me mentally and 
physically tough while also affording me...lifelong friends".

Headline: Sydney Hiance
Desc:
Sydney starred at soccer at Highlands and at the University of Kentucky as goalkeeper. At Highlands she compiled an incredible record, 
with a goals against average of 0.20 her senior year, and was named, among other things, Gatorade Kentucky Player of the Year 
and Cincinnati Enquirer Player of the Year. At Kentucky she compiled one of the best shutout records in U.K. history. She 
graduated from U.K. in 2011 with a degree in elementary education.

She served as a substitute teacher in the Ft. Thomas school system and coached at the prestigious Kings Soccer 
Academy in Wilder, Kentucky, also finding time for an International Fitness Association (IFA) certification.  Sydney is currently
pursuing a management career in the private sector, but maintains a strong interest in coaching.

When we asked how she felt about her Highlands preparation, Sydney said, "I think Highlands more than prepared me for my 
college career both as an athlete and also as a student. It is hard for me to believe that I would be where I am now without the 
help from the wonderful people at Highlands and especially my soccer coach Nina Kearns".
